questions.text: Iodide pump in thyroid gland is an example of
questions.solution:
Passive transport moves substances across the cell membrane without energy, including diffusion (simple and facilitated) and osmosis.

Active transport requires energy to move substances against their gradient, either through primary or secondary active transport.

Others are Carrier type transport and vesicular transport.

Option A: Primary active transport uses ATP directly (e.g., sodium-potassium pump, calcium pump, potassium-hydrogen pump).

Option B: Secondary active transport relies on an electrochemical gradient, not ATP (e.g., sodium-calcium exchanger, iodine pump).

Option C: Carrier transport involves proteins moving molecules across the membrane, either actively or passively.It can be uniporter, symporters and antiporters.

Option D: Vesicular transport: Many substances transported across the cell membrane by endocytosis and exocytosis.



Key takeaways:

Primary active transport uses ATP (e.g., sodium-potassium pump), while secondary uses an electrochemical gradient (e.g., sodium-calcium exchanger).

choices.text: Insulin release from beta cell of pancreas
LDL cholesterol internalization by LDL receptor

questions.text: Identify the type of transport given in the below image and choose the correct example of this transport.
questions.solution:
• Option B: Insulin is released from pancreatic beta cells through exocytosis, triggered by calcium changes from hormone binding.

Incorrect options-

  • Option A: Glucose transport involves facilitated diffusion by GluT4 in adipose tissue and sodium-dependent absorption via GluT1 in the intestines.
  • Option C: LDL is taken up by cells via receptor-mediated endocytosis, primarily using apo B-100 binding to receptors in clathrin-coated pits.
  • Option D: The sodium-potassium pump is an active transport mechanism that maintains low intracellular sodium and high potassium levels through ATP hydrolysis.

Key takeaways: Insulin release from beta cells involves Ca2+-triggered exocytosis, common in membrane remodeling and macromolecule secretion.

questions.text: Oxidation of long chain fatty acids are taken place in
questions.solution:
Option A: Endoplasmic reticulum involved in biosynthesis of proteins, glycoproteins, lipoproteins, drug metabolism, ethanol oxidation, synthesis of cholesterol (partial).

Option B: Mitochondria involved in beta oxidation of fatty acids (C16, C18), Electron transport chain, ATP generation, TCA cycle, ketone body production, urea synthesis (part), heme synthesis (part), gluconeogenesis (part), pyrimidine synthesis (part).

Option C: Ribosomes involved in protein synthesis.

Option D: A modified form of β-oxidation is found in peroxisomes and leads to the breakdown of Long chain fatty acids (C20, C22).

Key takeaways: Long-chain fatty acids are oxidized in peroxisomes to shorten them before further oxidation in mitochondria.

questions.text: On reduction, Glucose converts in to
questions.solution:
Reduction of aldehyde or ketone group of monosaccharides produces sugar alcohol

  • Glucose - Sorbitol (Glucitol), responsible for diabetic cataract
  • Galactose - Galactilol (Dulcitol), responsible for cataract in galactosemia
  • Mannose - Mannitol, Used in treatment of cerebral edema & Osmotic diuresis
  • Glyceraldehyde - Glycerol, Used to reduce edema locally
  • Ribose - Ribitol

Important monosaccharides:

Option A: Sucrose is a disaccharide made up of glucose and fructose, present in cane and beet sugar, non-reducing sugar

Option B: Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. Simultaneously, myoinositol levels fall. All these are responsible for diabetic cataract. In experimental animals, sorbitol accumulation and myoinositol depletion, as well as diabetic cataract, can be prevented by aldose reductase inhibitors.

Option C: On reduction, mannose is converted into mannitol. Mannitol is osmotically active, commonly used to reduce cerebral edema.

Option D: Galactose is monosaccharide, can be reduced to galactitol (dulcitol). Galactose is a substrate for aldose reductase, forming galactitol, which accumulates in the lens of the eye, causing cataract. Accumulation of galactitol is responsible for cataract in galactosemia, very characteristic features of galactosemia.

Key takeaways: Aldose reductase inhibitors prevent sorbitol accumulation, myoinositol depletion, and diabetic cataracts by blocking glucose reduction.

choices.text: It acts as a lubricant in the joints
It is present in the seminal fluid enabling sperm to entry into the ovum
It is a component of synaptic vesicles
It is made up of repeating unit of D-Glucoronic acid and N-acetyl-D-glucosamine

questions.text: All of the following are true about Hyaluronic acid, except
questions.solution:
Option A & Option C: Hyaluronic acid It is present in connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid and vitreous humor. It serves as a lubricant in joint cavities. It is also present as component of synaptic vesicles.

Option B: Hyaluronidase enzyme (not hyaluronic acid) is present in the seminal fluid enabling sperm to entry into the ovum.

Hyaluronic acid is present as a gel around the ovum. It is cleared by hyaluronidase enzyme (present in seminal fluid), enabling entry of sperm into the ovum, so help in fertilization.

Option D: It is composed of repeating units of D-Glucuronic acid and N-Acetyl D glucosamine held together by beta (1-3) glycosidic bond.

Key takeaways: Hyaluronic acid is present in connective tissues, synovial fluid, and around the ovum, composed of D-Glucuronic acid and N-Acetyl D-glucosamine linked by β(1-3) bonds, and cleared by hyaluronidase during fertilization.

choices.text: Keratan sulphate has a role in maintaining the shape of eyeball
Heparin has an important role in to prevent intravascular clotting
Chondroitin sulphate contributes its role in cartilage to its compressibility and weight bearing capacity
Dermatan sulphate is present in heart valves and blood vessels also

questions.text: All of the following are true about heteropolysaccharides, except
questions.solution:
Option A: Keratan sulphate play role in maintaining corneal transparency. Dermatan sulphate has structural role in sclera and help in maintaining shape of eyeball.

Option B: Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in liver, lung, and skin. It is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI, but its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin.

Option C: Chondroitin sulphate have role in compressibility of cartilage and weight bearing capacity.

Option D: Dermatan sulfate has a widespread distribution in tissues, and is the main GAG in skin. It is also present in blood vessels, heart valves, cornea, sclera etc. Evidence suggests it may play a part in blood coagulation, wound repair, and resistance to infection.

Key takeaways: Keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency, while dermatan sulphate supports scleral structure and helps preserve the shape of the eyeball.

questions.text: Wolman's disease is due to deficiency of
questions.solution:
Option A: Wolman's disease is due to deficiency of cholesterol ester hydrolase in lysosomes. It results in increase in VLDL in blood.

Option B: 17 alpha hydroxylase enzyme deficiency syndrome is a rare genetic disorder of steroid biosynthesis that causes decreased production of glucocorticoids and sex steroids.

Option C: HGPRTase enzyme deficiency leads to Lesch Nyhan syndrome.

Option D: Deficiency of peroxisomal matrix proteins can lead to adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) (Brown-Schilder's disease) characterized by progressive degeneration of liver, kidney and brain. It is a rare autosomal recessive condition. The defect is due to insufficient oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) by peroxisomes

Key takeaways: Wolman's disease is a rare, inherited lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of lipids in organs like the liver, spleen, and adrenal glands, resulting in severe growth failure, hepatosplenomegaly, and early death.

questions.text: Which phospholipid is involved in blood coagulation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glycerophospholipids containing choline (phosphatidylcholines, commonly called lecithins) are the most abundant phospholipids of cell membrane and represent a large proportion of the body's store of choline. Choline is important in nervous transmission, as acetyl choline, and as a store of labile methyl groups.

Dipalmitoyl lecithin is a very effective surface-active agent and a major constituent of the surfactant preventing adherence, due to surface tension, of the inner surfaces of the lungs. Its absence from the lungs of premature infants causes respiratory distress syndrome.

Option B: Phosphatidylethanolamine (cephalin) and phosphatidylserine (found in most tissues) are also found in cell membranes. Phosphatidylserine also plays a role in apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Option C: Phosphatidylinositol is a precursor of second messengers. Phosphorylated phosphatidylinositols are minor components of cell membranes, but play an important part in cell signaling and membrane trafficking. Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PiP2), for example, is cleaved into diacylglycerol and inositol trisphosphate upon stimulation by a suitable hormone agonist, and both of these acts as internal signals or second messengers.

Option D: Cardiolipin found in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function. Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathologic conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism, and Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).

Sphingomyelins:

  • Location: Found in the outer leaflet of the cell membrane and abundant in lipid rafts.
  • Function: Present in myelin sheaths of nerve fibers, involved in cell signaling and apoptosis.
  • Composition: No glycerol; yields fatty acid, phosphoric acid, choline, and sphingosine upon hydrolysis.
  • Ceramide Formation: Sphingosine plus fatty acid forms ceramide, also found in glycosphingolipids.

Key takeaways: Cephalin (phosphatidylethanolamine) is a phospholipid essential for maintaining cell membrane integrity and acts as a cofactor in blood coagulation, facilitating the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

questions.text: Lecithin: Sphingomyelin (L:S) ratio in amniotic fluid is an important indicator used to evaluate
questions.solution:
• Lung surfactants are essential for normal lung function, produced by epithelial cells, and reduce surface tension to prevent alveolar collapse.
  • Key constituents include dipalmitoyl lecithin, phosphatidyl glycerol, cholesterol, and surfactant proteins A, B, and C, with dipalmitoyl lecithin being the primary surfactant.
  • Sphingomyelin is synthesized before the 28th week of gestation, while lecithin levels increase as fetal maturity progresses.
  • The lecithin-sphingomyelin (LS) ratio in amniotic fluid indicates fetal lung maturity, with a ratio of 2 signifying full maturity.
  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) occurs due to low surfactant levels, primarily in premature infants who do not produce enough dipalmitoyl lecithin.

So Option B is correct option.

Key takeaways: Lung surfactants, mainly dipalmitoyl lecithin, reduce alveolar surface tension, and the lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio in amniotic fluid indicates fetal lung maturity, with low surfactant levels causing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants.

questions.text: Gangliosides can bind with viruses and toxins like
questions.solution:
• Gangliosides are complex glycosphingolipids derived from glucosylceramide, containing one or more sialic acid molecules, primarily neuraminic acid (NeuAc).
  • They are abundant in nervous tissues, contributing to the stability of paranodal junctions and ion channel clusters in myelinated nerve fibers.
  • Autoantibodies to GM1 disrupt lipid rafts and affect peripheral motor nerves, highlighting their role in cell-cell recognition and as receptors for hormones and toxins (e.g., cholera toxin).
  • The simplest ganglioside is GM3, consisting of ceramide, glucose, galactose, and NeuAc; GM1 is a more complex ganglioside known to be a receptor for cholera toxin in the human intestine.
  • In GM nomenclature, "G" stands for ganglioside, "M" indicates a monosialo species, and the subscript represents the number based on chromatographic migration.

Gangliosides, complex glycosphingolipids enriched in nervous tissues, are crucial for the stability of nerve fiber structures and cell communication. The simplest form, GM3, evolves into GM1, a receptor for cholera toxin, with nomenclature indicating their structure and complexity based on sialic acid content.

So Option A is correct option.

Key takeaways: Gangliosides, complex glycosphingolipids containing sialic acid, are abundant in nervous tissues, stabilizing ion channels and cell recognition, with GM1 serving as a receptor for cholera toxin.

questions.text: Which of the following structure of amphipathic lipids is involved in gene transfer?
questions.solution:
Lipids are generally insoluble in water due to predominance of nonpolar hydrocarbon groups, but contain polar groups making them amphipathic.

  • Amphipathic lipids orient at oil-water interfaces, forming structures like bilayers, micelles, liposomes, and emulsions, with various biological and clinical significance.
  • Option A: Micelles form at critical concentrations of amphipathic lipids, aiding in fat digestion and lipid absorption.
  • Option B: Liposomes, formed by sonicating amphipathic lipids, consist of lipid bilayers enclosing aqueous medium and are used as drug carriers and for gene transfer.
  • Option C: Bilayers of amphipathic lipids are fundamental to biological membranes; emulsions are larger particles stabilized by emulsifying agents like phosphatidylcholine.
  • Option D: Glycolipids are non-phosphorylated lipids containing carbohydrates and ceramide, such as glucocerebroside and galactocerebroside, prevalent in nervous tissues.

Ceramide + Glucose → Glucocerebroside

Ceramide + Galactose → Galactocerebroside

Key takeaways: Liposomes are spherical lipid bilayers formed by sonicating amphipathic lipids in water, used for targeted drug delivery, gene transfer, and topical applications.

choices.text: It occurs due to defect in ABC (ATP binding cassette transporter) protein
It increases the risk of coronary heart disease
Orange colour tonsils are seen in this disease
It occurs due to deficiency of Lipoprotein lipase enzyme (LPL)

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics of Tangier disease, except
questions.solution:
Option A: Tangier disease occurs due to defect in ABC (ATP binding cassette transporter) protein, which is responsible for transfer of cholesterol from peripheral tissue to HDL. As a results plasma HDL level is low.

Option B: The impaired reverse transport of cholesterol in tangier's disease increases the risk of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease (heart attack).

Option C: Orange colour enlarged lipid laden tonsils are seen in tangiers disease. this disease.

Option D: Type I hyperlipoproteinemia occurs due to deficiency of Lipoprotein lipase enzyme (LPL). Also known as Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Hypertriacylglycerolemia occurs due to deficiency of LPL, abnormal LPL, or apo C-ll deficiency causing inactive LPL. Slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL. Low levels of LDL and HDL. No increased risk of coronary disease.

Key points about Tangier Disease

  • First described in patients from Tangier island in North-West Africa.
  • Examples of hypolipoproteinemias
  • Also known as Familial α-lipoprotein deficiency or Fish-eye disease or Apo A-I deficiencies.
  • Relatively benign, autosomal dominant condition.
  • Characterized by a defect in the efflux (flowing out) of cholesterol from cells, and reduction of HDL levels in the blood.
  • The biochemical defect is the absence of "ATP-Binding Cassette Transporter-1" (ABC1), which is involved in transferring cellular cholesterol to HDL. So, plasma HDL is low and alpha band is not seen in electrophoresis. Cholesterol esters are accumulated in tissues.
  • Manifestations are large orange yellow tonsils, muscle atrophy, recurrent peripheral neuropathies and atherosclerosis.

Key takeaways: Familial α-lipoprotein deficiency, is an autosomal dominant condition marked by low HDL levels due to the absence of ATP-Binding Cassette Transporter-1, leading to cholesterol accumulation and symptoms such as orange-yellow tonsils.

questions.text: Identify the amino acid derivative
questions.solution:
Option A: DOPA (dihydroxy phenylalanine), derived from tyrosine. It is a neurotransmitter. DOPA serves as precursor for the pigment melanine, dopamine, nor epinephrine & epinephrine.

Option B: SAM (S-adenosyl methionine) is active methyl donor in transmethylation reaction, derived from methionine.

Option C: Gamma amino butyric acid (GABA) is a derivative of glutamic acid. It is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. Involved in ammonia toxicity. Gabapentin can pass blood brain barrier and can form GABA in brain.

Option D: All Dopamine, SAM & GABA are derived from amino acids, so amino acid derivatives.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Identify the following amino acid.
questions.solution:
Option A: Arginine is an amino acid containing basic side chains.

Options B & Option C: Threonine & Serine are aliphatic amino acids containing hydroxyl groups.

Option D: Asparagine is an amino acid containing amide group.

Key takeaways: Threonine and serine are aliphatic amino acids that contain hydroxyl groups, making them polar and hydrophilic, and they play essential roles in protein structure and function.

choices.text: All alpha helices found in proteins are right handed
Beta hairpin motif is most commonly seen motif in proteins
All peptide bonds in proteins exist in cis form
Denaturation disrupts all the structure of the proteins

questions.text: Following statement is true about structure of protein
questions.solution:
Option A: α helix and β pleated sheet are secondary structures described by Pauling and Corey in 1951.

  • α helix characteristics:
    • Most common and stable conformation.
    • Spiral structure with an average of 3.6 amino acids per turn and a distance of 1.5 Å between residues.
    • Right-handed is common; left-handed is rare due to L-amino acids.
    • Proline and hydroxyproline disrupt α-helix formation.

Option B: Tertiary structure describes spatial relationships among secondary structural elements, forming super secondary motifs like β-α-β and β hairpin, with β-α-β being the most common.

Option C: Peptide bonds link amino acids via a CO-NH linkage between the carboxyl group of one amino acid and the amino group of another.

  • Characteristics of peptide bonds:
    • Partial double bond character (1.32 Å), rigid, and trans in nature.
    • Limited rotation due to rigidity, but side chains can rotate (Ramachandran angles).

Option D: Denaturation leads to loss of secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures without altering the primary structure; it breaks non-covalent bonds but preserves peptide bonds.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: All of the following are biologically important peptides, except
questions.solution:
Oligopeptides: Composed of 10 or fewer amino acids; some are biologically active.

  • Option A: Oxytocin and Vasopressin (ADH)
  • Nanopeptides with 9 amino acids.
  • Secreted by the posterior pituitary.
  • Oxytocin: Stimulates uterine contractions during labor and milk ejection during lactation.
  • ADH: Prevents diuresis by promoting water reabsorption.
  • Option B: Glutathione
  • A tripeptideconsisting of glycine, cysteine, and glutamic acid (Gamma Glutamyl Cysteinyl Glycine).
  • Maintains erythrocyte membrane integrity.
  • Option C: Creatinine
  • An anhydride form of creatine, which is a muscle protein made of glycine, arginine, and methionine.
  • Option D: Myoglobin
  • A protein, not a peptide.
  • Additional Peptides:
  • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH):
    • Tripeptide(Glu-His-Pro) secreted by the hypothalamus; stimulates TSH secretion.
  • Angiotensin I and II:
    • AT I has 10 amino acids; AT II has 8 amino acids; involved in blood pressure regulation and can cause hypertension.
  • Gramicidin S:
    • Contains 10 amino acids, has a circular shape, produced by Bacillus brevis, and used as an antibiotic.

Key takeaways: Myoglobin is a globular protein that binds oxygen in muscle tissues. Although it is often discussed alongside peptides, myoglobin is a larger and more complex protein, not classified as a peptide.

choices.text: Precipitation of protein by UV rays

questions.text: Which of the following is the method for precipitation of proteins?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Organic solvents reduce available water, leading to protein precipitation; alcohol acts as a strong protein precipitating agent and has disinfectant properties.
  • Option B: Lyophilization is freeze-drying, removing water from frozen products under vacuum.
  • Denaturation (Options C & D): UV rays and heat cause protein denaturation, a mild precipitation reaction; heat coagulation is irreversible.

Protein Precipitation Overview:

  • Stability Factors: Protein stability relies on charge and hydration; polar groups attract water, and neutralizing charges or removing hydration causes precipitation.
  • Precipitation Methods:
    1. Salting Out: Adding neutral salts (e.g., ammonium sulfate) removes hydration shells, precipitating proteins; higher molecular weight proteins require less salt.
    2. Isoelectric Precipitation: Proteins are least soluble at their isoelectric pH (e.g., casein at pH 4.6).
    3. Precipitation by Organic Solvents: Organic solvents decrease water availability and dielectric constant, leading to precipitation.
    4. Precipitation by Heavy Metal Ions: Heavy metals can complex with proteins, causing precipitation; toxic metals (e.g., copper, mercury) can harm normal gastrointestinal proteins.
    5. Precipitation by Alkaloidal Reagents: Agents like phosphotungstic acid lower pH, causing positively charged proteins to precipitate with negatively charged ions.

Key takeaways: The addition of organic solvents like alcohol reduces water availability and dielectric constant, causing protein precipitation and explaining alcohol's disinfectant effect.

questions.text: Match the enzyme classes and examples.
questions.solution:
IUB Classification: Developed a system for enzyme nomenclature with unique names and codes based on reactions and substrates.

Enzyme Classes:

  1. Oxidoreductases: Catalyze oxidation and reduction (e.g., dehydrogenases, oxidase).
  2. Transferases: Transfer moieties (e.g., kinases, aminotransferases).
  3. Hydrolases: Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of bonds (e.g., pepsin, trypsin).
  4. Lyases: Cleave bonds by atom elimination, forming double bonds (e.g., aldolase).
  5. Isomerases: Catalyze structural changes within a molecule (e.g., epimerase).
  6. Ligases: Join molecules, coupling reactions to ATP hydrolysis (e.g., synthetase).
  7. Translocases (7th class): Catalyze movement of ions or molecules across membranes (e.g., ornithine translocase).

So, Option D is the correct option.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Match the coenzyme and the group transferred by the coenzyme.
questions.solution:
Enzyme Components:Enzymes often contain small molecules or metal ions essential for substrate binding or catalysis.

Types of Molecules:

  • Prosthetic Groups: Tightly bound to enzymes and essential for their activity.
  • Cofactors: Non-protein chemical compounds required for enzyme activity, often metal ions.
  • Coenzymes: Organic molecules that assist enzymes, often derived from vitamins.
  • Vitamins: Water-soluble vitamins, especially the B complex, provide crucial components for many coenzymes.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Iodoacetate combines with SH group of serine and inactivates enzyme
In non- competitive inhibition, Km value is lowered, Vmax is increased
In competitive inhibition, Km value is lowered.Vmax is unchanged
Disulfiram, a drug used in de-addiction treatment that non- competitively inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase for treatment in alcoholics

questions.text: Identify the correct sentence regarding enzyme inhibition
questions.solution:
Iodoacetate: Inactivates enzymes by binding to the -SH group of cysteine residues in the active site (Option A).

Non-Competitive Inhibition:

  • Km remains unchanged; Vmax is reduced.
  • Inhibitor binds to a different site, distorting the enzyme's shape.
  • Substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition.
  • Examples include cyanide and heavy metals (Option B).

Competitive Inhibition:

  • Km is increased; Vmax is unchanged.
  • Inhibitor competes with substrate for the active site and resembles its structure.
  • Reversible by increasing substrate concentration.
  • Example: Malonate for succinate dehydrogenase (Option C).

Disulfiram: Non-competitively inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, used in alcohol de-addiction treatment (Option D).

Key takeaways: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a different site, reducing Vmax without changing Km, while in competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes for the active site, increasing Km but leaving Vmax unchanged.

questions.text: Which isoenzyme of ALP (alkaline phosphatase) is present in placenta?
questions.solution:
Alpha-1 ALP: Found in biliary canaliculi (Option A).

Alpha-2 Heat Labile ALP: Present in the liver (Option B).

Alpha-2 Heat Stable ALP: Found in the placenta (Option C).

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP):

  • A nonspecific enzyme that hydrolyzes various compounds.
  • Optimal pH: 9-10; activated by magnesium and manganese, with zinc as a constituent ion.
  • Localized in cell membranes (ectoenzyme), associated with transport in liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa.
  • Produced by osteoblasts, linked to calcification.
  • Normal serum ALP levels: 40-125 U/L; higher in children due to osteoblastic activity.
  • Six isoenzymes based on the organ of production.
  • Regan Isoenzyme: A placental-like isoenzyme found in ~15% of carcinoma cases (lung, liver, gut).

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Z DNA is left handed and contains 12 base pair in each turn
Hoogsteen pairing enables the formation of triplex DNA
The DNA synthesis takes place in S phase of cell cycle
Junk DNA is transcriptionally active part of DNA and easily digested by nuclease enzymes

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about DNA, except
questions.solution:
Option A:

  • Six forms of double-stranded DNA exist (A-E and Z).
  • B-DNA: Right-handed double helix, 10 base pairs per turn, found under physiological conditions (low salt, high hydration).
  • A-DNA: Right-handed double helix, 11 base pairs per turn.
  • Z-DNA: Left-handed double helix, 12 base pairs per turn.

Option B:

  • Hoogsteen Pairing: Involves N7, O6, and N6 of purines, enabling triplex DNA formation; guanosine-rich DNA favors tetraplex formation.

Option C:

  • DNA synthesis occurs in the S phase of the cell cycle.

Option D:

  • Junk DNA: Mostly transcriptionally inactive, associated with nucleosomes, not digestible by nucleases, considered nonfunctional until further studied.

Key takeaways: A-DNA, B-DNA, and Z-DNA are structural variants of DNA, with B-DNA being predominant in physiological conditions, Hoogsteen pairing allows triplex DNA formation, DNA synthesis occurs in the S phase, and "junk DNA" is transcriptionally inactive and associated with nucleosomes.

choices.text: It can work as the universal energy currency
It can act as cofactors for various enzymes
It can act as secondary messenger to action of hormones
It can act as intermediates in the metabolic pathways

questions.text: All of the following are the function of nucleotides, except
questions.solution:
Purine and Pyrimidine Nucleotides:

  • Serve as precursors of nucleic acids and play diverse metabolic roles.

Option A:

  • ATP and ADP: Key donors/acceptors of phosphoryl groups; essential for energy transduction and oxidative phosphorylation.

Option B:

  • Nucleotides linked to vitamins form coenzymes, not cofactors.

Option C:

  • Cyclic Nucleotides (cAMP and cGMP): Act as second messengers in hormonal regulation; GTP and GDP are crucial in signal transduction pathways.

Option D:

  • Nucleosides linked to sugars/lipids serve as biosynthetic intermediates.
  • UDP-glucose and UDP-galactose: Involved in sugar interconversions and starch/glycogen biosynthesis.
  • CDP acylglycerol: An intermediate in lipid biosynthesis.

Metabolic Regulation:

  • Nucleotides regulate enzymes through ATP-dependent phosphorylation, allosteric effects of ATP, ADP, AMP, and CTP, and control of oxidative phosphorylation rate by ADP.

Medical Applications:

  • Synthetic purine/pyrimidine analogs used in chemotherapy for cancer and AIDS, and as immune response suppressors in organ transplantation.

Key takeaways: Nucleotides, when combined with vitamins or their derivatives, form essential coenzymes that play crucial roles in various enzymatic reactions. Unlike cofactors, coenzymes are organic molecules that are modified during the reaction and participate actively in the catalytic process.

choices.text: A-anticodon arm , B-acceptor arm , C-DHU arm
A-acceptor arm , B-DHU arm , C-anticodon arm.
A-DHU arm , B-acceptor arm , C-anticodon arm
A-DHU arm , B-anticodon arm , C- acceptor arm

questions.text: Identify the arm present on the t-RNA
questions.solution:
RNA Characteristics:

  • Length: 74 to 95 nucleotides.
  • Comprises about 20% of total cellular RNA.
  • Generated by nuclear processing of precursor RNA.

Function:

  • Acts as an adapter, translating mRNA nucleotide sequences into specific amino acids.
  • At least 20 tRNA species exist, corresponding to each of the 20 amino acids required for protein synthesis.

Structure:

  • Primary structure allows folding and intrastrand complementarity, forming a cloverleaf-like secondary structure.
  • Contains four main double-stranded arms (or stems) connected by single-stranded loops:
    • Acceptor Arm: Terminates in CpCpAOH, where the amino acid is attached.
    • The three nucleotides at the 3′-OH group are added post-transcriptionally by a specific nucleotidyl transferase.

Charging Process:

  • The appropriate amino acid is attached to the tRNA via specific aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases, linking it to the acceptor arm.

Additional Features:

  • D, TψC, and extra arms help define specific tRNA types.

Key takeaways: tRNA molecules translate mRNA sequences into specific amino acids, featuring a cloverleaf structure with four double-stranded arms, where amino acids are attached to the acceptor arm by aminoacyl tRNA synthetases.

questions.text: Identify the type of regulation of the enzyme given in the diagram
questions.solution:
Option A: Allosteric Regulation

  • Allosteric enzymes have an allosteric site separate from the active site.
  • Regulatory molecules can enhance (activators) or inhibit (inhibitors) enzyme activity.
  • Effect is partially reversible; excess substrate increases Km and reduces Vmax.
  • Cooperativity: Binding of substrate to one subunit affects others, resulting in a sigmoidal saturation curve.
  • Activators shift the curve to a hyperbolic profile; inhibitors produce more pronounced sigmoidicity.

Option B: Covalent Modification

  • Involves the addition or removal of groups to/from enzyme proteins via covalent bonds.
  • Rapid and reversible; affects enzyme activity.
  • Common examples include phosphorylation and dephosphorylation.

Option C: Enzyme Induction & Repression

  • Involves increased or decreased synthesis of enzymes.
  • Regulates through mechanisms affecting gene expression.

Option D: Competitive Inhibition

  • Inhibitors compete with substrates for the active site.
  • Inhibitors resemble substrates structurally.
  • Reversible; excess substrate can overcome inhibition.
  • Km is increased, but Vmax remains unchanged.

Key takeaways: Allosteric regulation involves enzymes with an allosteric site that allows regulatory molecules to enhance or inhibit activity, resulting in a sigmoidal saturation curve due to cooperativity, with increased Km and reduced Vmax.
